ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A greater ability to converse in Japanese and also present relatively novel topics to classmates.
I was able to reach intermediate proficiency in Japanese. I can hold pretty proficient conversation and read a lot more Japanese now.
I think my Japanese developed greatly in this course, especially with regards to grammar usage and reading Kanji.
Japanese grammar and communication skills.

I learned Japanese grammar and vocabulary.

Unfortunately, given my commitments to my other classes this semester, I did not have the time to do much of the coursework (including journals... I'm sorry!), and as a result I got much less out of it than I would have hoped.

I was able to further my Japanese ability. The course specifically focused on learning Japanese while also interspersing bits of Japanese culture which helped to contextualize a lot of the course material.

I continued to develop the ability to express thoughts and ideas, ask questions, read, and listen in Japanese. This semester I became more comfortable expressing longer and more complex thoughts, and learned new grammar structures that allowed to create more nuanced responses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was extremely organized and as students, we always had ample time to prepare for assignments and assessments. I do however wish that there was more emphasis on helping students that were behind the curve catch up to the intermediate level expected of the class.

I think the strength of this course was how organized and engaging it was. Although there's not much room for improvement, I wish we had more time to practice coming up with answers on the spot and not on reviewing homework. I also with my TA for clinic was more willing to be strict with my Japanese. Clinic was not as beneficial for me as in past semesters.
Overall, I think this course is very well structured. It certainly moves at a very fast pace, but the way in which we clearly use the textbook and move from lesson to lesson works very well.
Perfect course setting.
The projects were fun.
The class was very good as is! There is a lot of work from time to time, but this is mostly an unavoidable problem in the pursuit of a foreign language, especially one like Japanese.

The strengths of this course are that it meets everyday but was always relaxed and fun. Most of class time is just answering questions, going over the homework, and practicing dialogue. I think this is a strength because language learning takes a long time, and progressing slowly in a low-stress environment helped prevent me from burning out. I think the many skits and speeches we did were also a strength, as they helped get me more comortible presenting in Japanese. 

One weakness may be that we did not practice formal or academic writing much at all, but honestly this may just not be in important skill at our Japanese level. I expect that as we get to advanced levels writing will become more stressed. Overall this was a great course and I'm not sure there is much I would change.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes - especially if you want to get better at speaking Japanese. Yamaguchi sensei is incredible and did a great job at ensuring that students had ample time to meet with her for anything and everything.
Yes absolutely! I really enjoyed this class and L4 really feels like a turning point because a lot of less serious students drop after L3. Yamaguchi sensei is super supportive and I learned a ton.

I definitely would recommend this course to another student! Although L4 Japanese is certainly difficult, I think that this course truly allows one to use Japanese on the daily and develop not only as a speaker, but as a learner of Japanese language and society. I would say to students in similar positions to me (heritage speaker, not quite ready for L4 with regards to reading and writing), that if possible, level down.
Yes! The Japanese course here is great!
I would recommend this course to anyone wishing to continue their Japanese learning.
Yes! If you are interested in furthering your Japanese skills, this is a fantastic course to take even if you've already finished your language requirement with L3.

Yes I would! 4th year Japanese is really exciting because it was when I really started to feel familiar with the language and when I started to be able to express a wide variety of thoughts and Ideas!
